text: hey everyone yeah yeah yeah here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new city morgue
album vol 2 as good as dead this is a
brand new LP from the music duo Zilla
Connie and Sol semilla who a few years
ago decided to assemble under the
umbrella of city morgue
their debut LP hell and high water
dropped back in 2018 which was pretty
one-dimensional but it still showed a
lot of potential for the growing
popularity of trap metal at the time two
years later and the trend isn't really
that much more popular than it was just
a little while ago but what's exciting
and encouraging is that city morgue is
back with a more dynamic sound toning it
down on some of the very niche and kind
of gimmicky riff heavy beats working in
more melodic choruses mellower tracks
and instrumentals that pull quite a bit
from Punk and emo and alternative rock
there are songs on this thing that are
just straight bloody murderous horror
core which was not as prevalent in
influence on the last LP with city
morgue now delivering freakier lyrics
backed up not only with these bumping
trap beats but also the types of synths
and string samples you typically hear in
a scary movie which pretty much makes
tracks like Thresh and c4 what hasn't
changed about city morgue though is that
they still cut to the chase they are
still blunt this thing is 17 tracks 35
minutes not a whole lot of wiggle room
on these cuts many of them just
disappear before two minutes Zilla and
moolah both very much have a similar
energy on this one too they are
screaming at the top of their lungs on
most of these tracks it's edgy as [ __ ]
though again on those more mellow and
melodic tracks Zilla does make an
attempt to sing more choruses and he
holds his own now not every one of these
low-key cuts on this record are amazing
for example the balloons whose hook
really drags on forever still adding
these kinds of songs on the album does
make for a more versatile and enjoyable
listening experience overall I will say
I think volume 2 here is better than
volume 1 even if it is still a little
hit or miss
there are of course some tracks here
that are so short or they cut out so
abruptly they leave a lot to be desired
also some tracks here don't exactly
stand out for the best reasons for
example of the song whoa whoa whoa whoa
you really do have to wonder how much
effort truly went into the hook on that
one especially since there are some
supremely good choruses here the song
baby wipes I think finishes before any
real momentum gets going the verse on it
from mullah is very mild and contains a
very weird weird reference to baby wipes
but again I'm mostly wondering on this
record of 17 tracks what is this one
minute and 23 seconds really adding to
the whole thing especially since its
shoulder to shoulder with tracks that
are equally aggressive tracks that are
much catchy er still what you do get
outside of these relative low points in
the tracklist here is a series of
gruesome bangers with a lot of attitude
with a lot of volume the vast majority
of the lyrics here are cartoonishly
violent the appeal is pretty much in how
over-the-top it all is like on this set
of bars where moolah is talking about
there being a potato on his gun and he's
not making hash browns or Zilla on the
tracks splinter go apeshit I shoot up
your house I do not party doot doot doot
like we playing baby Sharky ha ha I'm a
rat killer shredder damn Master Splinter
Glock paint pictures bloody @ mall
centers if I took a shot for every time
that indiscriminate bullet spray was
referenced in the lyrics on this thing I
might be dead before 3/4 of the album
were done I don't think the
entertainment value of the album though
boils down simply to this thing just
being a cheap and violent thrill there
are some very good instrumentals here
there are some head nodding grooves
there are some solid flows the energy is
infectious and again the choruses are
pretty good from track to track as well
it's so visceral its aggression is
infectious I can imagine
every single city morgue show just being
this giant mosh pit
highlights beyond this include the
opening track neck brace which I'm
pretty sure includes a Death Grips
interpolation it goes that goes if
it goes right yeah oh good Mack the hook
on inferior is a lot more mystical by
comparison but it's still a heavyweight
track with its very creepy and sparse
lead melodies and buzzing guitar samples
tracks like these balance out with the
gloomier cuts on the album and on these
songs we do hear and see a lyrical
switch on these tracks
Zillah and moolah are unafraid to
address other topics like depression
isolation suicidal thoughts drug
addiction like on the track Drano let me
say not only is this one of these sadder
cuts here but it's also very smart to
include Denzel curry on one of these
tracks from the record not only is it a
solid feature but it's not the turn that
I think most fans are expecting when
they hear that city morgue and Denzel
curry are going to team up I'm sure most
assumed oh it's gonna be the hardest
[ __ ] on planet Earth but instead this
track is so much darker more demented
and depressing referencing tears going
down the drain the song the give up is
even sadder by comparison lyrically it
is a suicide note of sorts talking about
dealing in those feelings fighting them
turning them over and contemplating them
I think there is a bit of a lull in the
middle of the record where Zilla and
moolah start taking some tracks on their
own which I appreciate that
this changes the tracklist up a little
bit but I think that they work best
together at least in the context of city
morgue I don't see what a solo track
from either of them really brings to an
album like this even if I do think their
refrains on 16 toes are pretty good and
the idk feature around this point on the
album is good - things start picking up
once more toward the end we have amazing
hard-hitting cuts like dirt nap they
want a job they want a dirt nap with the
track mouthguard city morgue easily
saved one of the best courses for last I
like to break [ __ ] make [ __ ] build it
and destroy it honestly as somebody who
as a teenager loved edgy angry hip-hop
like ICP that
kind of stuff liked DMX this this like
is very much kind of plugging into into
those feelings things get a bit less
aggressive for the last couple of songs
screaming at the rain is one of the more
melodic cuts here beautiful chorus
mullah and his verse rapid fires bars
about losing a friend depending on drugs
to get through emotional pain it's
pretty simple it's not flashy but the
bluntness of this verse from a man who
is rarely vulnerable on this thing is is
truly what gives it impact the song
peeling scabs has some pretty decent
synth passages on it too I think the
guitar samples which are very twang in
and sad and somber work very well into
the instrumental but this track doesn't
really have any more weight the
matically or instrumentally or lyrically
than any other here especially some of
the sad songs because it is one of the
sadder songs and basically with this
being the closer i'm just feeling a
little underwhelmed like this could have
been bigger this could have been a
grander statement something that ties
the entire record up but it feels just
as cut to the chase as everything else
here which i guess does leave me wanting
more but with a new project i would love
to hear city morgue looking at things a
bit more big picture in terms of how all
of these tracks are coming together so
even though I do think city morgue have
overcomes some of those issues of being
one-dimensional being so OneNote on
their last record III think there is
room to grow here of course this style
of hip-hop is not going to be for
everyone it's just going to be too edgy
for some people but still I think this
project is a cool and thrilling shock to
the system it is as much a blade to the
throat as it is a cry for help in some
ways I'm feeling a light 2007 on this
one transition have you given this album
a listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate a you're the best
you're the best what should i review
next hit the like if you liked please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well over here next to my head
is another video that you can check out
hit that up or the link to subscribe to
the channel Anthony Fantana city morgue
forever
